text: THE SPHINX AT GIZEH
title: Fifty-One Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: I saw the other day the Sphinx's painted face.
title: Fifty-One Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: She had painted her face in order to ogle Time.
title: Fifty-One Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And he has spared no other painted face in all the world but hers.
title: Fifty-One Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Delilah was younger than she, and Delilah is dust. Time hath loved
title: Fifty-One Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: nothing but this worthless painted face.
title: Fifty-One Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: I do not care that she is ugly, nor that she has painted her face, so
title: Fifty-One Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: that she only lure his secret from Time.
title: Fifty-One Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Time dallies like a fool at her feet when he should be smiting cities.
title: Fifty-One Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Time never wearies of her silly smile.
title: Fifty-One Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: There are temples all about her that he has forgotten to spoil.
title: Fifty-One Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: I saw an old man go by, and Time never touched him.
title: Fifty-One Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Time that has carried away the seven gates of Thebes!
title: Fifty-One Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: She has tried to bind him with ropes of eternal sand, she had hoped
title: Fifty-One Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

author: Dunsany, Lord

author: Dunsany, Lord

text: If she ever finds his secret we will put out his eyes, so that he shall

author: Dunsany, Lord

text: find no more our beautiful things--there are lovely gates in Florence

author: Dunsany, Lord

text: that I fear he will carry away.
title: Fifty-One Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: We have tried to bind him with song and with old customs, but they
title: Fifty-One Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: only held him for a little while, and he has always smitten us and
title: Fifty-One Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: mocked us.
title: Fifty-One Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: When he is blind he shall dance to us and make sport.
title: Fifty-One Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Fifty-One Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: children, and can hurt even the daisies no longer.

author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Then shall our children laugh at him who slew Babylon's winged bulls,
title: Fifty-One Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Fifty-One Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: of his hours and his years.

author: Dunsany, Lord

author: Dunsany, Lord

text: where the sarcophagus is. Thence we will lead him out when we
title: Fifty-One Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: give our feasts. He shall ripen our corn for us and do menial work.

author: Dunsany, Lord
